Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Culture and Coordination in Global Engineering Teams

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Construction engineering provides the foundation for society: the buildings, bridges, roads and other infrastructure we use every day. Engineering work has become increasingly complex, and big engineering projects are almost always undertaken by teams of engineers whose members are multicultural and distributed around the globe. Effective coordination is crucial for success, yet recent research suggests that team coordination practices vary with national culture. Experts have warned that engineering education fails to prepare engineers for these differences.

We will use scripts theory, which lies at the intersection of the fields of social psychology and artificial intelligence, to characterize the culturally-specific coordination practices of engineering teams, introducing the notion of "cultural coordination scripts." We will 1) characterize and understand the coordination scripts of several specific cultures, 2) show how cultural coordination scripts are intertwined with technical training and technical tasks and 3) determine how differences in cultural coordination scripts in multi-cultural globally-distributed teams affect their capacity to coordinate highly precise work and achieve innovative, safe, timely and cost-effective outcomes. We seek to predict likely points of coordination failure. Data collection will include unobtrusive longitudinal observation of the coordination activities of mono-cultural and multi-cultural collocated and distributed engineering design teams.

This research program will help engineers -- and others who work in multicultural, multi-national project teams -- become more adept in anticipating and working across different cultural expectations related to project coordination. Recommendations will be developed for engineering education and practice. Cultural differences in coordination practices are understudied across domains of application, so our work will provide new knowledge concerning this central team process. We also offer a new approach to capturing the complexity of teamwork "an approach grounded in scripts theory" that has the potential to influence research across disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this research were to develop theoretical and empirical understanding of cultural differences in how complex project work is coordinated.  We have sought to help engineers—and others who work in multicultural, multi-national project teams--become more adept in anticipating and working across different cultural expectations related to project coordination. We also sought to develop knowledge and provide recommendations to improve engineering education and practice, as well as management education and practice. Neither the coordination nor the culture literatures have given serious attention to cultural differences in approaches to project coordination, despite enormous evidence in projects in the field that such differences result in costly and dangerous errors.

Our empirical research program indeed revealed differences in how project teams in Germany, the United States, Australia, Japan and India prefer to coordinate their work, even in projects matched on other characteristics. For example, we found distinct differences in the problem-solving approaches that German and American engineers use in meetings. German engineers used a highly iterative approach to problem solving relative to American engineers. They cycled back to discuss and refine task and product definitions more than twice as often as American engineers who were carrying out an identical task. The American engineers used a more linear process in their problem-solving discussions, rarely revisiting task and product definitions after reaching an initial consensus on these matters. Both processes are successful within their own cultural context. When Germans and Americans work together in a multicultural team, however, their different underlying assumptions about the best approach to problem solving create conflict and project delays.  As another example, our research showed that the role structures of matched construction projects in Germany and Australia are quite different in role definition, in allocations of authority, responsibility and risk, in nomenclature, and in lines of communication and work interface.

We distilled the key aspects of such coordination differences into the new concept of cultural coordination spirit. We provide examples from multiple cultures. The concept of cultural coordination spirit can be a useful stimulus for future research and a useful guide for global project managers and engineering teams. Cultural coordination spirit is one aspect of our larger theoretical contribution, which is a focus on what we call cultural coordination scripts. Our theoretical and empirical work fills gaps in both the coordination and cultural literatures, neither of which have focused on cultural differences in approaches to coordination.

We have published papers in the organization studies, international business, civil and environmental engineering, and cross-cultural psychology literatures. We have made numerous scholarly presentations around the world, and given workshops worldwide on our methodology. We also have shared our thinking and our results with companies, with schools of engineering, architecture and business, and with graduate students in international business, engineering, architecture, and cross-cultural psychology. We have developed new courses or new course segments for a business school, an engineering school, and an architecture school.

Our work will continue to seek to improve the coordination of international projects, especially engineering and construction projects. This allows the benefits of international specialization and collaboration to be realized more efficiently, economically, safely and successfully.
